_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
Dole Packaged Foods, LLC - Atwater Operations (Dole), Atwater, California Facility (Facility) is located at 7916 West Bellevue Road, Atwater, California, approximately 0.5 miles north of State Route 99 (Golden State Highway). The Facility process and packages fruit and vegetable products. Anhydrous ammonia is used in the Facility's Plant 1 and Plant 2 refrigeration system processes. 

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Dole has developed a California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program in general accordance with the requirements of California Code of Regulations Title 19, Division 5. California Environmental Protection Agency, Chapter 2, and Federal EPA requirements, 40 CFR Part 68 Risk Management Plan (RMP), and federal OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) 29 CFR 1910.119 and California OSHA 8 CCR 5189  to enhance existing anhydrous ammonia safety and emergency response programs. Dole is committed to worker and public safety through investment in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration systems. Dole's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. Dole has developed an Emergency Response Plan to respond to a release of ammonia in the unlikely event that a chemical release does occur at the Facility.

Process Description
Dole has two anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems at the Facility to support its primary operation of processing and freezing fruit. The refrigeration processes are separated between Plant 1 and Plant 2. Plant 1 and Plant 2 are two-stage closed-loop ammonia refrigeration systems.

The Plant 1 refrigeration system process is composed of the following key components:
High stage compressors
Booster compressors
Condensers
HPR
Anhydrator
Intercoolers
Recirculator packages
Evaporators 
Heat Exchangers

The Plant 2 re

frigeration system process is composed of the following key components:
High stage compressors
Booster compressors
Condensers
HPRs
Anhydrators
Intercooler
Recirculator packages
Evaporators 
Heat Exchangers

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The prevention program elements of CalARP RMP are implemented by Dole to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia for refrigeration. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being followed. The CalARP/RMP/PSM prevention program elements:
Management System
Offsite Consequence Analysis
Five-Year Accident History
Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis
Operating Procedures
Training Programs
Mechanical Integrity
Management of Change
Pre-startup Safety Review
Compliance Audits
Incident Investigation
Employee Participation
Hot Work Permits
Contractor Safety
Emergency Planning and Response
Trade Secrets (none associated with the ammonia refrigeration system)

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no reportable releases of ammonia at the Dole Facility in the past 5 years.

Emergency Response Program 
Dole is a responding facility and has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP). The ERP provides Facility personnel general guidelines and procedures in preparing for and responding to emergency situations that may occur at the Facility, such as responding to a fire, an unplanned or accidental release of a hazardous material, medical emergencies, bomb threats, site evacuation, etc. The ERP also provides resources for agency notification, coordination among Facility personnel and outside responders, and internal and/or external use in emergency planning/preparedness. Emergency response actions are coordinated with local emergency response agencies annually.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Dole performed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) in April 2020 and generated a list of re

commendations to improve safety and mitigate potential releases. Dole will address PHA recommendations within the 2 ½-year time frame set forth in the January 1, 2015, CalARP requirements. These changes to improve safety include:
	P2-RC01 and RC02 motor rebuilds 
	Adding Ammonia horn and strobes in Production areas and freezers where ammonia 
        equipment/piping is present
	Upgrade Recirculator Control panels in order to phase out obsolete panels
	Upgrade main refrigeration PLC in order to phase out obsolete PLC
	Install catwalk for all Blast 15 evaporators for cleaning and inspection access 
	Replace Cyber key access to Badge scanners access for critical rooms such as Ammonia 
        Engine Rooms, Recirculator Rooms, and Boiler Rooms 
	Upgrade current Cornell pumps to hermetically sealed Cornell pumps for P1-RP03, P2-RP32, 
        and P2-IQF4&5-RP01 
	Replace Hansen level probes to danfoss cable style for more accurate level readings. 
	Replace Plant 2 HX04 and Plant 2 HX05 with a Plate and frame (small footprint) package 
	Replace Plant 2 Condensers P2- EC01, EC04, EC03, and EC05


Management responses and actions will be consistent with Dole's commitment to safe and environmentally responsible operation. Dole recognizes that the CalARP/RMP/PSM program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its Facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Dole continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. Dole will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the CalARP/RMP/PSM program, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with Dole's practices, and Dole will maintain the most current version onsite. T
hus, the most current version of the CalARP/RMP/PSM program and related documents and elements maintained onsite may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to regulatory agencies.
